div.head: IF YOU CALL IT THINKING.
div.p: At a recent dinner of the Southern Society, former Attorney General George W. Wickersham said, according to "The New York World":

"No people can thrive and advance if, side by side and working with them, are 10,000,000 who are disenfranchised from ail voice in government. God knows that this is a difficult problem, and God knows how it will be solved, but it cannot be solved by denying to any one, be he black or yellow or red, the right of a voice in making the laws by which he shall be governed and in the choice of the men who shall govern him."
This is evidently a woman suffrage speech?
Oh, no, Mr. Wickersham is a strong anti-suffragist.
What did he mean then?
That he does not think a woman is any one.

div.head: PEARLS FROM THE WOMAN'S PROTEST (ANTI-SUFFRAGE).
div.p: "Their absolute impotence to control or deliver the vote of enfranchised women is proved."
More, give us more anti arguments like this!
"In Silver Bow County, Montana, 2,000 voters didn't vote on the suffrage question."
This appears to be an argument against manhood suffrage, showing that men don't use the vote when they get it.
"In the dry and suffrage parade in Columbus the Sunday before election five little colored girls marched carrying a banner with the inscription, 'We are the men of to-morrow.' "
The "Antis" are alarming themselves unnecessarily.
The little girls were mistaken.
"If the suffragettes wished to stop war they should have thrown their bombs at the Krupp factory or the English fleet."
It is impossible to tell whether this is an indorsement of war or an incitement to militancy.

"The suffragists disdain woman's work, but they do not seriously aspire to men's. Where are they to be found? So far we have seen but one mention of any organized effort on their part in English papers. . . . In the meantime, Lady French, in the direct traditional manage of the women the gets results, is asking for thousands of scarfs and belts to clothe the soldiers and employing regularly a large number of women in executing her commands."
Lady French is doing most of her work with the National Union of Woman Suffrage Societies in the distribution of relief and care of non-combatants.
Mrs. Harley, Sir John French's sister, an active member of the National Suffrage Society, is organizing a girls' cadet corps for aid to the injured.
Mrs. Despard, president of the Woman's Freedom League, Sir John's other sister, established one of the first free clinics in the East End of London.

div.head: PEACE HATH HER BATTLEFIELDS.
div.p: ("The loss of 500,000 men as the result of the present warfare could be made good in less than ten years through complete abstinence from alcoholic beverages by all the inhabitants of Russia.—Arthur Hunter, Chairman of the Medico-Actuarial Investigation, at the meeting of Life Insurance Presidents.)
Four of the five states that voted for prohibition this year are woman suffrage states.

div.head: A BATTLE HYMN.
div.p: (“It is far better policy for the saloon men and brewers to take a firm stand against woman suffrage and fight than it is to pretend friendliness in the hope that the women will appreciate it if they get the ballot and will vote in favor of the saloon,.”—National Forum, Butte, Mont.)
